Good morning, Doctor.
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Good morning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Could you please introduce yourself.
speaker: MR. BAER

text: I'm Maxwell Stepanuk, Jr.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And, sir, can you please tell us what type of medicine you practice.
speaker: MR. BAER

text: I'm an orthopedic surgeon.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is the field of orthopedics?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: It's the branch of medicine that deals with injuries and pathology of bones, joints, and muscles, every data structures such as nerves and tendons.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long, sir, have you been a surgeon?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Oh, it's about 43 years or so now.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you please describe what you had to do to become a surgeon.
speaker: MR. BAER

text: I graduated from Temple University and then did a year of graduate work at Villanova.  This was followed by four years of medical school at the Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine.  I then went to the Detroit, Michigan area where I did an internship and a four year residency in orthopedic surgery at Oakland General Hospital.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, through the course of your career, did you ever have any teaching appointments?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Yes.  I taught from basically day one.  I always taught interns and students. In fact, I was program director for the Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine for the Orthopedic Residency Program.  I was director for about 25 years in charge of the training of residents learning to become orthopedic surgeons.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, are you currently board-certified?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What does it mean to be board-certified?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: I'm board-certificated in orthopedic surgery.  It means that you're a competent orthopedic surgeon.  In my case, I had to take a written exam followed by an oral exam.  And then after you're out in practice for a number of years and accumulate some major cases, they want to do a survey.  They look at your x-rays, review your charts, and if you pass, you're deemed a certified or a competent orthopedic surgeon.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sir, are all doctors or all physicians board-certified?

text: Okay, Doctor.  All right, Doctor, we're going to point your attention to Maritza Rodriguez.  Sir, we're here on behalf of Maritza Rodriguez related to her treatment following an accident that occurred on January 31, 2018; is that correct?

text: Yes.

text: During your testimony, I'm going to be asking you for some of your opinions.  I ask that you not give any of those opinions unless you can do so within a reasonable degree of medical certainty; is that okay?

text: Yes, it is.

text: That is correct.

speaker: MR. BAER

text: Yes.

speaker: MR. BAER

text: That's the report that I generated after evaluating Ms. Rodriguez.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, I'm going to ask that if you need to, refer to your report as needed during the course of your testimony here today; is that understood?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, Doctor, in a moment I'm going to ask you to walk us through your evaluation of Ms. Rodriguez step-by-step.  But before I do that, I'd like to know the answer to one very important question.  That is, after examining Ms. Rodriguez, reviewing her records, studies that are referenced in your report, did you find anything wrong with her?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Yes, I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Please tell us what it was.
speaker: MR. BAER

text: I found that she had a cervical strain and sprain, a right upper extremity radiculopathy, right rotator cuff tear, and aggravation right AC joint arthritis.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you please explain in greater detail what those injuries are.
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Cervical strain and sprain is stretching of the ligaments and muscles in the neck.  It's like a sprained ankle in your neck. The right upper extremity radiculopathy is tingling, numbness that radiates down the right arm.  A rotator cuff tear -- we can go to a model.  This is the shoulder.  It happens to be a left shoulder.  This is the collarbone.  This is the humerus, the arm bone.  The rotator cuff is in here.  The green is a bursa.  When you have shoulder problems, you get bursitis. (Indicating). The rotator cuff in this case was torn in this area, completely torn all the way through, but it didn't retract, meaning it didn't separate.  Talk about the AC joint, the acromion is this part.  The clavicular, the clavicle is this part (indicating).  So it's an acromion clavicular AC joint arthritis.  So there is arthritis in this joint pushing down where the rotator cuff tear adding the injury.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Doctor, please tell us what the other injuries are.
speaker: MR. BAER

text: We did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Doctor, would you please tell us what was the most serious of those injuries.
speaker: MR. BAER

text: The right rotator cuff tear.

text: Do you have an opinion within a reasonable degree of medical certainty as to the extent or the seriousness of those injuries which you described for us?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: It's my opinion that the injuries were serious.  They were permanent injuries and her prognosis was poor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are these conditions painful conditions, Doctor?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Yes, they are.

speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there any other findings with respect to that shoulder?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Of note is that there was no muscle atrophy.  When a rotator cuff tear is old, it begins to atrophy.  It does separate. It does retract and the head of the humerus rides up.  None of that was present on this exam.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. BAER

speaker: MR. BAER

text: Yes.

speaker: MR. BAER

text: Yes, I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And performing a physical examination, is that something that you would do with your clinical patients?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's the importance of doing a physical examination?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: To see what is actually wrong with the patient upon examining, touching the patient, and evaluating the patient.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, when you performed this examination of Ms. Rodriguez, did you take a history from her?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Yes, I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did she tell you?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Well, she complained of neck pain, right shoulder pain with occasional numbness in the right arm, injured in a motor vehicle accident on 1/31/18.  She was a driver of a car.  She was injured when she was struck on the passenger's side by another car that went through a traffic light.  The impact caused her vehicle to spin.  She was wearing her seatbelt.  The airbags deployed.  She injured her right shoulder as she was swung about by the impact.  She went to St. Luke's Hospital in Allentown and was treated and released. She complained to me of a stabbing, sharp pain in her right shoulder. She said her shoulder pain was severe.  She had pain with overhead use of her shoulder with occasional numbness down the right arm.  She had mildly, severe pain in her cervical spine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, Doctor, Ms. Rodriguez saw you one year and five months almost to the day from when this crash occurred; is that accurate?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you saw her that 17 months later, she was still complaining of pain in her neck?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Still had pain in the neck.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And still had problems with the shoulder; is that accurate?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Doctor, did you perform any tests on Ms. Rodriguez as part of your examination?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Yes.  I examined her neck and she had pain in the neck muscle upon palpating or pressing on the muscles.  She had a full neck range of motion.  The main problem was pain in the right shoulder.  She had pain about the entire right shoulder.  There was no instability.  There was no weakness.  She did have a significant decrease of motion to the right elbow. She could only abduct and flex to 45 degrees.  Abduction means bringing it up from your side, and that was 45 degrees. Usually, it's up overhead 180 degrees.  Flexion is bringing the arm forward.  That was only 45 degrees, normal is 180.  External rotation or bringing the arm rotated outwards was 80 degrees.  That's pretty much normal.  Internal rotation is rotating the arm downward.  That was only 30 degrees, normal is about 70 to 80 degrees.  She had positive impingement signs. These are signs that the rotator cuff is irritated when you put the arm through certain motions.  She had no crepitus.  The reflexes were equal.  She had a decrease in sensation to the right arm.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, is this a normal exam?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What was abnormal about the exam?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: Significant abnormality was the loss of shoulder motion with the impingement signs.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, please tell us more. What else, if anything, did you do as part of this examination?
speaker: MR. BAER

text: That was it as far as the physical exam.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. BAER

text: She did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. BAER

text: She told me stabbing, sharp pain in her right shoulder, pain is severe.

Her right shoulder pain and right rotator cuff tear, aggravation of the right AC joint arthritis was a direct result of her 1/31/18 accident.

That's pretty much it except that if her cervical symptoms and disc pathology persists and becomes intolerable she will require surgery on her neck.

speaker: MR. BAER

Pain control injections is $6,000 per series of injections, and I've recommended two series of injections costing $12,000.  The cost for the cervical arthrodesis is $125,000.  The cost for ongoing treatment for medication and occasional therapy is $5,000 a year for at least the next five years.

(Deposition ended at 11:47 a.m.) C E R T I F I C A T E I do hereby certify that I am a Notary Public in good standing, that the aforesaid testimony was taken before me, pursuant to notice, at the time and place indicated; that said deponent was by me duly sworn to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth; that the testimony of said deponent was correctly recorded in machine shorthand by me, to the best of my ability, and thereafter transcribed under my supervision with computer-aided transcription; that the deposition is a true and correct record of the testimony given by the witness; and that I am neither of counsel nor kin to any party in said action, nor interested in the outcome thereof. WITNESS my hand and official seal this 6th day of September, 2019. <%signature%>
